facts.text: Appeal filed as Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1959 by special leave from judgment and order dated April 14, 1959 of the former Bombay High Court Rajkot Branch in Criminal Appeal No. 84 of 1958

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 223 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and ordered dated April 14, 1959, of the former Bombay High Court  Rajkot Branch  at Rajkot in Criminal Appeal No. 84 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant and two others convicted by Additional Sessions Judge, Gohilwad, under sections 302 and 201 IPC for murder of Kanji, sentenced to life imprisonment under 302 and seven years rigorous imprisonment under 201, sentences concurrent

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and two others were companyvicted by the Additional Sessions Judge, Gohilwad, under ss. 302 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code for the murder of Kanji and they were sentenced to imprisonment for life under the former section and to seven years rigorous imprisonment under the latter. The sentence were companycurrent.

facts.text: High Court set aside conviction of Nanji Ravji but upheld convictions and sentences of appellant and Karamshi Bhawan

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court set aside the companyviction of Nanji Ravji but upheld the companyvictions and sentences of the appellant and Karamshi Bhawan. The appellant has Come in appeal to this Court by Special leave.

facts.text: Deceased Kanji had illicit connection with Shrimati Shantu, sister of Karamshi, and followed Smt. Baghu, sister of appellant

anchor.surface_text: The deceased Kanji was rather an unsavoury character in village Chiroda and it is alleged that he had a illicit companynection with Shrimati Shantu the sister of Karamshi and also used to follow about Smt. Baghu the sister of the appellant for a similar object.

facts.text: Five days before occurrence, appellant Karsan, Karamshi, Nanji and Gumansinh approver met and decided to murder Kanji

anchor.surface_text: It is stated that five days before the occurrence the appellant Karsan, Karamshi, Nanji and Gumansinh approver met and decided to murder the appellant.

facts.text: Gumansinh approver was to decoy deceased to Vadi of appellant where murder was to be committed

anchor.surface_text: With that object in view Gumansinh approver was to decoy the deceased to the Vadi of the appellant and there the murder was to be companymitted.

facts.text: At about sunset on March 19, 1958, deceased decoyed to place and murdered by appellant with blows from sharp cutting instrument Dharia

anchor.surface_text: At about sunset on March 19, 1958, the deceased was decoyed to the place as previously arranged and there he was murdered by the appellant who gave him a few blows. with a sharp cutting instrument called Dharia.

facts.text: Dead body wrapped in scarf of deceased and carried by appellant to dry bed of river and buried in pit

anchor.surface_text: According to the statement of the approver the dead body was wrapped in the scarf of the deceased and was carried by the appellant from the place of the murder to the dry bed of the river and there it was burried in a pit.

facts.text: On March 26, 1958, brother of deceased reported disappearance to police and suspected three uncles of appellant

anchor.surface_text: Nothing was heard of the murder or of the deceased till on March 26, 1958, a brother of the deceased made a report to the police about his disappearance and that he suspected the three uncles of the appellant, subsequently the appellant and the other accused persons were taken into custody by the police.

facts.text: One accused in custody went to village, sought help of Shamji and Manilal PW, confessed to them, they reported to police

anchor.surface_text: One of them while in the custody of the police, was allowed to go to the village and he asked the help of Shamji and Manilal P.Ws. He also made a companyfession to them and they reported the matter to the police.

facts.text: On March 31, 1958, Gumansinh and Karamshi made confessions recorded by Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1958, Gumansinh and Karamshi made companyfessions which were recorded by a Magistrate.

facts.text: Between March 26 and March 31, 1958, recoveries of various articles made

anchor.surface_text: Between March 26 and March 31, recoveries of various articles were made.

facts.text: At instance of appellant, dead body and head of deceased recovered from distant well

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant, it is stated, the dead body and then the head of the deceased was recovered from a distant well.

facts.text: On March 28, 1958, at instance of Nanji, scarf discovered in pit where dead body allegedly first buried

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of Nanji on March 28, 1958 a scarf was, discovered in the pit in which the dead body was according to the approver, buried.

facts.text: Hairs on scarf similar to hairs of appellant and deceased per Chemical Examiner

anchor.surface_text: On the scarf, there were some hairs which on analysis by the Chemical Examiner were found to be similar to the hairs of the appellant and of the deceased.

facts.text: On March 27, 1958, at instance of appellant, silver buttons stained with human blood discovered from his field

anchor.surface_text: A day previous, i. e. March 27, 1958, at the instance of the appellant silver buttons which were stained with human blood were discovered from the field of the appellant

facts.text: At instance of appellant, small stick like button belonging to deceased found

anchor.surface_text: at small stick like a button belonging to the deceased was also found at his instance.

facts.text: High Court rejected confession of Karamshi as not voluntary

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companyfession of Karamshi on the ground that it was number voluntary.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Nanji due to no corroboration of approver's statement regarding him

anchor.surface_text: It acquitted Nanji on the ground that there were numbercorroboration in regard to him of the approvers statement, the place where the dead body was buried was number discovered at his instance, his production of stick and shirt and trousers from his house was of numberconsequence, and the oral evidence was companytrary to the medical evidence and Karamshis companyfessional statement companyld number be used against Nanji.

facts.text: High Court accepted testimony of approver as reliable for appellant

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the appellant the High Court accepted the testimony of the approver as being a reliable piece of evidence.

facts.text: High Court relied on discovery of dead body trunk and head at instance of appellant

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court did rely upon the discovery of the dead body of the deceased, i.e. the trunk and the head, at the instance of the appellant and of the blood-stained buttons also at his instance

facts.text: High Court attached importance to scarf from pit with hairs of appellant and deceased

anchor.surface_text: and attached importance to scarf recovered from the pit where the dead body was alleged to have been first buried and which had hairs both of the appellant as well as of the deceased.

facts.text: In pit dug up in dry river bed, dead body not found, only ulna bone and heel of human foot found

anchor.surface_text: The approver had stated that the dead body was buried in a pit in the dry bed of the river but when that pit was dug up the dead body was number found there and only a piece of ulna bone and a heel of a human foot were found

facts.text: Appellant argued scarf belonged to his father, not him

anchor.surface_text: The recovery of the scarf, it was pointed out, was an innocuous circumstance because on the evidence produced it had number been shown to belong to the appellant but to his father

issues.text: Whether the evidence of the approver is corroborated in material particulars connecting the appellant with the offence

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the appellant that the evidence of the approver, even though it had been accepted as true, was not corroborated in material particulars connecting the appellant with the offence. On the other hand it was contradicted. The approver had stated that the dead body was buried in a pit in the dry bed of the river but when that pit was dug up the dead body was not found there and only a piece of ulna bone and a heel of a human foot were found and all these recoveries had been made earlier and so could not be called corroborative in material particulars.

issues.text: Whether the Chemical Examiner's evidence regarding the hairs on the scarf is admissible under s. 45 of the Evidence Act and sufficient to connect the appellant to the offence

anchor.surface_text: the evidence of the Chemical Examiner was not sufficient to prove that the hairs on the scarf were of the appellant or of the deceased because the Chemical Examiner was certainly not expert on this matter and his evidence was, not admissible under s. 45 of the Evidence Act, and at the most, according to the Chemical Examiners report the hairs resembled those of the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the recovery of the dead body, trunk and head at the instance of the appellant leads only to an inference of an offence under s. 201 or also under s. 302

anchor.surface_text: It was further submitted that the statement in regard to the recovery of the trunk and the head will only show that the appellant knew where the trunk and the head were, which at the most would lead to an inference of an offence under s. 201 and not of s. 302. What the law requires in the case of an accomplices evidence is that there should be such corroboration of the material Parts of the story connecting the accused with the crime as will satisfy reasonable minds that the approver can be regarded as a truthful witness.

issues.text: Whether the discovery of blood-stained silver buttons at the instance of the appellant raises a presumption of his participation in the murder

anchor.surface_text: The discovery of the buttons with bloodstains at the instance of the appellant is a circumstance which may raise the presumption of the participation of the appellant in the murder, In Wasin Khan v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , it was held that the recent and unexplained possession of stolen property would be presumptive evidence against a prisoner on a charge of robbery as also of a charge of murder.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court finds sufficient evidence connecting appellant

holdings.text: What the law requires in the case of an accomplice's evidence is that there should be such corroboration of the material parts of the story connecting the accused with the crime as will satisfy reasonable minds that the approver can be regarded as a truthful witness. The corroboration need not be direct evidence of the commission of the offence by the accused. If it is merely circumstantial evidence of his connection with the crime it will be sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: What the law requires in the case of an accomplices evidence is that there should be such companyroboration of the material Parts of the story companynecting the accused with the crime as will satisfy reasonable minds that the approver can be regarded as a truthful witness. The companyroboration need number be direct evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates and applies established rule from precedents like Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v. State of Hyderabad, emphasizing circumstantial corroboration suffices for reliability.

holdings.text: None of these recoveries in the circumstances of this case are corroborative of the statement of the approver to the extent of connecting the appellant with the offence committed. On the other hand, they are somewhat contradictory of the statement.

anchor.surface_text: None of these recoveries in the circumstances of this case are companyroborative of the statement of the approver to the extent of companynecting the appellant with the offence companymitted. On the other hand, they are somewhat companytradictory of the statement because the pania  scarf  which was found in the pit has number been stated to belong to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approver's specific details on dharia, scarf ownership, burial pit, and head disposal not matched by recoveries, which contradict (body not in pit, scarf not stated as appellant's).

holdings.text: The discovery of the buttons with bloodstains at the instance of the appellant is a circumstance which may raise the presumption of the participation of the appellant in the murder.

anchor.surface_text: The discovery of the buttons with bloodstains at the instance of the appellant is a circumstance which may raise the presumption of the participation of the appellant in the murder, In Wasin Khan v. The State of Uttar Pradesh  1 , it was held that the recent and unexplained possession of stolen property would be presumptive evidence against a prisoner on a charge of robbery as also of a charge of murder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies doctrine of recent unexplained possession analogously to blood-stained articles of deceased, presuming participation in violence per Wasin Khan v. State of Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.text: The mere fact that the dead body was pointed out by the appellant or was discovered as a result of a statement made by him would not necessarily lead to the conclusion of the offence of murder. But there are other circumstances which have to be considered.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that the dead body was pointed out by the appellant or was discovered as a result of a statement made by him would number necessarily lead to the companyclusion of the offence of murder. But there are other circumstances which have to be companysidered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recovery of body shows knowledge (potentially s.201 only), but combined with buttons, scarf, hairs infers active participation in murder (s.302).

holdings.text: From the microscopic examination of the hairs it is possible to say whether they are of the same or of different colours or sizes and from the examination it may help in deciding where the hairs come from.

anchor.surface_text: The writers on medical jurisprudence, however, have stated that from the microscopic examination of the hairs it is possible to say whether they are of the same or of different companyours or sizes and from the examination it may help in deciding where the hairs companye from. In Taylors Medical Jurisprudence  1956 Edn.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical jurisprudence authorities like Taylor's confirm microscopic hair analysis identifies origin/group, supporting Chemical Examiner's similarity finding despite non-specialist status; cites cases of individual identification.

holdings.text: In our opinion this would be sufficient evidence in the circumstances of the present case to connect the appellant with the commission of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, we have besides the evidence of the approver three important facts which companynect the appellant with the companymission of the offence. His pointing out the dead body, his pointing out the silver buttons of the deceased which were stained with human blood and the presence of his hairs on a pania  scarf  on which there were the hairs of the deceases also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulation of pointing out body/trunk/head, blood-stained buttons, appellant's scarf from pit with both parties' hairs sufficiently connects appellant to murder despite weak approver corroboration.

precedents.cited_proposition: Corroboration of accomplice evidence need not be direct evidence of commission of offence; circumstantial evidence connecting accused with crime sufficient if it satisfies reasonable minds of approver's truthfulness; nature varies with circumstances.
